body: @apnewberry This sounds like a great suggestion, thank you.

issue.title: Added subprocess.run explicit set `check` argument set checker. Closes #2848

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
<!--

Thank you for submitting a PR to pylint!

To ease the process of reviewing your PR, do make sure to complete the following boxes.

You can also read more about contributing to pylint in this document:
https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/blob/master/doc/development_guide/contribute.rst#repository
-->

## Steps

- [✓] Add yourself to CONTRIBUTORS if you are a new contributor.
- [✓] Add a ChangeLog entry describing what your PR does.
- [✓] If it's a new feature or an important bug fix, add a What's New entry in `doc/whatsnew/<current release.rst>`.
- [✓] Write a good description on what the PR does.

## Description
New checker for `check` arg in subprocess.run for better and explicit exception handling

## Type of Changes
<!-- Leave the corresponding lines for the applicable type of change: -->
|   | Type |
| ------------- | ------------- |
|   | :bug: Bug fix  |
| ✓  | :sparkles: New feature |
|   | :hammer: Refactoring  |
|   | :scroll: Docs |

## Related Issue

<!-- 
If this PR fixes a particular issue, use the following to automatically close that issue
once this PR gets merged:

Closes #2848 
-->
Closes #2848

issue.title: utils: ignore subprocess-run-check

repository.name: oss-fuzz
repository.description: OSS-Fuzz - continuous fuzzing for open source software.

issue.body:
"check" is omitted intentionally there.

A follow-up to https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/4101

issue.title: refactor: Consolidate init scripts into 1 & modernize
issue.body:
NOTE: This will require slight modification to the commands given at
cold.yeticold.com, disc.yeticold.com, warm.yeticold.com,
etc... (all of them).

The command would be:
py ~/yeticold/initialize.py MODE
where MODE is one of the following:
YetiColdPrimary
YetiColdSecondaryCreate
YetiColdSecondaryRecover
YetiHot
YetiWarm
BitcoinCoreOfflinePrimary
BitcoinCoreOfflineSecondary

Instead of having many files for different paths with substantially the
same code, all the common code was combined into a single script. The
differences were added as switches based on an input argument to the
script.

Error handling for the arguments was included. Where certain commands
could result in errors printed to the terminal, the stderr output was
passed to /dev/null to keep the terminal free from worrisome errors that
mean nothing to the user.

The system bash calls were also modernized with the latest recommended
practice as of Py3.5. This means using subprocess.run wherever possible.
Part of the proper use of this is to the returncode for success or
failure, and to explicitly check (or not check) for errors in the
execution of the command. In this case, all are false.
This is referenced in: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/2848

Also included are pauses in script execution to allow time for the flask
webserver to fully load before loading the first html page. This removes
the need for the user to manually reload the webpage (this comes across
as a broken user experience).

Finally, originally the many scripts all had the
`snap install network-manager`. This was unnecessary and undesirable for
a couple reasons:
1. Only the 2nd machine in YetiCold needs to have the network disabled.
2. In Ubuntu 18 and 20, network-manager is already installed.
There is no need to install it with SNAP and doing so silently disables
the network and leaves the user wondering what's wrong. They would need
to reboot in order for the network to work so the installation can
continue.

In the future, this practice should be reconsidered for a different
approach, even if manual with specific directions and warnings.

issue.title: refactor: Consolidate init scripts into 1 & modernize
issue.body:
NOTE: This will require slight modification to the commands given at
cold.yeticold.com, disc.yeticold.com, warm.yeticold.com,
etc... (all of them).

The command would be:
py ~/yeticold/initialize.py MODE
where MODE is one of the following:
YetiColdPrimary
YetiColdSecondaryCreate
YetiColdSecondaryRecover
YetiHot
YetiWarm
BitcoinCoreOfflinePrimary
BitcoinCoreOfflineSecondary

Instead of having many files for different paths with substantially the
same code, all the common code was combined into a single script. The
differences were added as switches based on an input argument to the
script.

Changed apt-get to apt because apt is suited better for end users and
has a nice graphical progress bar.

Error handling for the arguments was included. Where certain commands
could result in errors printed to the terminal, the stderr output was
passed to /dev/null to keep the terminal free from worrisome errors that
mean nothing to the user.

The system bash calls were also modernized with the latest recommended
practice as of Py3.5. This means using subprocess.run wherever possible.
Part of the proper use of this is to the returncode for success or
failure, and to explicitly check (or not check) for errors in the
execution of the command. In this case, all are false.
This is referenced in: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/2848

Also included are pauses in script execution to allow time for the flask
webserver to fully load before loading the first html page. This removes
the need for the user to manually reload the webpage (this comes across
as a broken user experience).

Finally, originally the many scripts all had the
`snap install network-manager`. This was unnecessary and undesirable for
a couple reasons:
1. Only the 2nd machine in YetiCold needs to have the network disabled.
2. In Ubuntu 18 and 20, network-manager is already installed.
There is no need to install it with SNAP and doing so silently disables
the network and leaves the user wondering what's wrong. They would need
to reboot in order for the network to work so the installation can
continue.

In the future, this practice should be reconsidered for a different
approach, even if manual with specific directions and warnings.

issue.title: refactor: Consolidate init scripts into 1 & modernize
issue.body:
NOTE: This will require slight modification to the commands given at
cold.yeticold.com, disc.yeticold.com, warm.yeticold.com,
etc... (all of them).

The command would be:
py ~/yeticold/initialize.py MODE
where MODE is one of the following:
YetiColdPrimary
YetiColdSecondaryCreate
YetiColdSecondaryRecover
YetiHot
YetiWarm
BitcoinCoreOfflinePrimary
BitcoinCoreOfflineSecondary

Instead of having many files for different paths with substantially the
same code, all the common code was combined into a single script. The
differences were added as switches based on an input argument to the
script.

Changed apt-get to apt because apt is suited better for end users and
has a nice graphical progress bar.

Changed unattended-upgrade to sudo apt upgrade so it spits out status
updates.

Error handling for the arguments was included. Where certain commands
could result in errors printed to the terminal, the stderr output was
passed to /dev/null to keep the terminal free from worrisome errors that
mean nothing to the user.

The system bash calls were also modernized with the latest recommended
practice as of Py3.5. This means using subprocess.run wherever possible.
Part of the proper use of this is to the returncode for success or
failure, and to explicitly check (or not check) for errors in the
execution of the command. In this case, all are false.
This is referenced in: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/2848

Also included are pauses in script execution to allow time for the flask
webserver to fully load before loading the first html page. This removes
the need for the user to manually reload the webpage (this comes across
as a broken user experience).

Finally, originally the many scripts all had the
`snap install network-manager`. This was unnecessary and undesirable for
a couple reasons:
1. Only the 2nd machine in YetiCold needs to have the network disabled.
2. In Ubuntu 18 and 20, network-manager is already installed.
There is no need to install it with SNAP and doing so silently disables
the network and leaves the user wondering what's wrong. They would need
to reboot in order for the network to work so the installation can
continue.

In the future, this practice should be reconsidered for a different
approach, even if manual with specific directions and warnings.

body: This feature conflicts with Pycharm check that says "argument equals to default parameter value". Also, it doesn't make much sense. Why did you choose only subprocess.run? Why not handle every default value for every function like def foo(handle_errors=False)? The answer for the last question is "default values are made exactly for this: to omit passing them explicitly".

I'm _considering_ disabling this checker by default for everyone at work as I've been unaware of anyone actually being tripped up by expecting an exception from `run()`.

As documented in its docstring help text and the subprocess module docs, `subprocess.run()` returns a `CompletedProcess` instance which contains all relevant information including exit status (returncode).

Not _every_ process means "error" when it exits non-zero.

Then again, I'm the subprocess maintainer, so perspective from a lot of users would be more useful than my opinion.

> Why did you choose only subprocess.run? Why not handle every default value for every function like `def foo(handle_errors=False)`? 

There are not very many functions with a default behavior of hiding errors, because it has tendency to cause incorrect behavior. That's presumably why it's in the Zen of Python, and why [newer APIs](https://trio.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference-io.html#trio.run_process) aren't designed that way.

Please don't quote the zen. It isn't a rule book. It is written
intentionally vague and contradictory so that you can justify all possible
decisions using it.

> Then again, I'm the subprocess maintainer, so perspective from a lot of users would be more useful than my opinion.

It's great to see maintainers interested in users' opinions! Even when I'm ultimately wrong I certainly appreciate being listened to.

> It isn't a rule book.

You're right of course, the Zen isn't gospel -- it's simply a concise and lighthearted way of highlighting certain design considerations. 🙂

However — I do think those are the dominant considerations in this case. In particular, when I see `subprocess.run(args)` during code review, I want to know what happens if the process fails, because I have an internal mental linter that tells me "warning: that function silently hides errors". But if I'm tired I might not notice, and even if I do notice, I'd rather a robot have warned the developer about it in advance so it doesn't need to go through a human review cycle. 

As you rightly point out,

> Not every process means "error" when it exits non-zero.

Likewise, not all exceptions raised are actually errors (`StopIteration` comes to mind). On the other hand, _very many_ processes do mean mean error when they exit nonzero. So if a subprocess call does silently suppress errors, the code can be clarified by saying "I actually do intend to do this otherwise risky thing". My preference would've been that `subprocess.run(check=True)` be the default, but that's not an option (for backward compatibility reasons). But we can write our calls to be either safe (`check=True`) or signposted (`check=False`) -- which, while verbose and unorthodox (passing the default value), is nonetheless the best option under the circumstances.

As a data point: In our internal codebase I see ~150 files passing an explicit `check=False` to `subprocess.run()` and <20 with a `# pylint: disable=subprocess-run-check` (out of thousands of subprocess.run calls, most written before pylint 2.4, roughly half of which seem to have `check=True`) so it seems to be having the intended effect.  People are being more explicit in their calls when using subprocess.run as a result.  Those who are annoyed are a minority and just disable it and move on.

@gpshead and @jtrakk thanks for this interesting discussion.
@gpshead if i correctly understand your last post, the experience you had with your codebase indicates that this pylint check is useful. Is that correct?
